subject: Re: today's big swing: Kirk Solves Email
body:
On Feb. 25, at 06:00 PM, Jeremy Stahl wrote:
Congrats, C. Kirk! Great piece. I like the analogies for dumb non-coders like myself and the"how's the email" jokes. I really want to try the thing (the GIFs made it look cool), at the same time I'm a bit daunted to actually physically download it.

From: <Kirk>, Chris <chris.kirk@slate.com>
Date: Wednesday, February 25, 2015 5:19 PM
To: 'Julia Turner' <julia.turner@slate.com>, 'Dan Kois' <dan.kois@slate.com>, "slateed@slate.com" <slateed@slate.com>, Alissa Neil <alissa@alissaneilpr.com>
Subject: Re: today's big swing: Kirk Solves Email

Thank you to everyone for reading and sharing! Thanks especially to Julia, John, and Dan, not only for giving the writing a lot of care and attention, but for letting me pursue this insane idea in the first place, and also to Dan Check for the crucial feedback during editing. Thank you to Juliana for jumpstarting my modeling career and to the rest of the Art team for making the piece look more beautiful than I'd ever imagine a big piece about email could be. Thanks also to Jennifer Lai for somehow making me sound coherent in the audio pieces.​ Even a commenter was happy, and that means my job was done.

From: Turner, Julia
Sent: Wednesday, February 25, 2015 3:28 PM
To: Kois, Dan; Slate Editors; Alissa Neil
Cc: Kirk, Chris
Subject: RE: today's big swing: Kirk Solves Email
 

Let me please second Kois—Chris did a terrific job with this piece and this project. He’s a marvelous, deft, clear and funny thinker and writer. Please read and share. Via email and otherwise.

 

Julia

 

From: Kois, Dan
Sent: Wednesday, February 25, 2015 12:41 PM
To: Slate Editors; Alissa Neil
Cc: Kirk, Chris
Subject: today's big swing: Kirk Solves Email

 

Hello Slate! Please join me in congratulating Chris Kirk on the official publication today of his totally fun, funny, fascinating, and provocative Fresca about his quixotic attempt to build his own email app. It's a chronicle of an impossible programming challenge that transforms into a meditation on the role email plays in all our lives, and the way this decades-old technology has become, as Chris calls it, "a beast of burden" onto whose back we've piled every kind of communication imaginable. He ends with a call to arms for citizens to rethink the way they use email that I'm going to start adhering to, just as soon as I send this email.

 

We all knew that Chris was an expert maker of interactives and a generator of clever ideas. But you maybe did not know what an elegant and funny writer he is! As a piece of tech writing for lay readers, his essay is splendid: While I was reading it, I was expertly fooled into believing that I actually understood the complicated infrastructure of email and the reasons it's such a mess. Through smart analogies, great visuals, and patient and careful writing, Kirk has written a piece that's a model of informed argumentation

 

The piece came together with a lot of support: from John Swansburg, who signed off on this somewhat odd but exciting pitch; Dan Check and other members of the dev team who offered helpful advice along the way; Julia Turner, who top-edited and asked all the right questions; Juliana Jiménez, who took those great photos; Holly Allen, who generated all the wonderful design elements, including the photo illustrations using Alex Eben Meyer's buzzing B-mails; Meg Wiegand, who copy-edited it carefully and also took charge of a very complicated publication process; and Jennifer Lai, who put together three terrific Plus bonuses, including a podcast where Kirk gets to vent at me for cutting a section of his piece.

 

Congrats Chris! Everyone else, PLEASE read and share and tweet and Like and congratulate Chris as well.
